citations.narrative:
There are two employees that are used as attendants, selling tickets, and feeding, watering and cleaning the enclosures.
These employees are not readily identifiable. During inspection there were several groups of people that were having
contact and feeding the animals. One of the groups was not visible to any attendant and had a child feeding a free
roaming baby emu. One of the employees was feeding the animals which left only one attendant to observe contact with
the animals. Due to the size of the facility and the numerous areas that allow public contact two attendants is not a
sufficient number.
Lack of a sufficient number of readily identifiable attendants can lead to injury to the animals and/or the public.
A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods
of public contact.
To be corrected by August 15, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Kristin Ray, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
There are two employees that are used as attendants, selling tickets, and feeding, watering and cleaning the enclosures. 
These employees are not readily identifiable. During inspection there were several groups of people that were having 
contact and feeding the animals. One of the groups was not visible to any attendant and had a child feeding a free 
roaming baby emu. One of the employees was feeding the animals which left only one attendant to observe contact with 
the animals. Due to the size of the facility and the numerous areas that allow public contact two attendants is not a 
sufficient number. 
Lack of a sufficient number of readily identifiable attendants can lead to injury to the animals and/or the public. 
A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must be present at all times during periods 
of public contact.  
To be corrected by August 15, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Kristin Ray, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
